title: Meet the half-term 'super-tutors' getting children into elite schools with mindfulness, yoga and smoothies
text:
In a brightly lit sports studio in the heart of Chelsea, six boys and one girl are lying flat-out on yoga mats. “This is your safe, relaxed, calm pose,” their instructor assures them in lullaby tones as she guides the children through their “Lion’s Breath”, a deep inhalation exercise that will, they are told, help focus their minds during the five hours of tuition that lie ahead.

It is the first day of the October half-term at Class Action, a “super-tutoring” club aimed at Britain’s elite. Aged between six and 11, the yogees are mostly the offspring of bankers and oil executives, plus one headmaster, who have each shelled out £1,500 for the five-day course.
